ShortDesc: In this seminar, we will take up poems from the three volumes Seamus Heaney completed between the 1995 Nobel Prize and his death in 2013.
Title: Helen Vendler on Seamus Heaney

MobileDesc: Jonathan Franzen opens the Poetry Center’s 77th season with a reading from his new novel, Purity, a dark comedy of youthful idealism, extreme fidelity and murder. As in The Corrections and Freedom, Franzen has created a cast of vividly original characters—Californians and East Germans, good parents and bad, journalists and leakers—whose interweaving fictional universe “illuminates, through the steady radiance of its author’s profound moral intelligence, the world we thought we knew” (The New York Times). After the reading, Franzen will be interviewed by his introducer, Mark Greif, author of The Age of the Crisis of Man and founding editor of n+1.
ShortDesc: Jonathan Franzen opens the Poetry Center’s 77th season with a reading from his new novel, Purity, a dark comedy of youthful idealism, extreme fidelity and murder.
Title: Jonathan Franzen

MobileDesc:
“The strength of love, the marvel of endurance and the power of generations—Sandra Cisneros sings to my blood,” wrote Dorothy Allison. Thirty years after The House on Mango Street, Sandra Cisneros publishes A House of My Own, a patchwork memoir of personal, political and literary pieces that span her career.

She is joined by Azar Nafisi, author of Reading Lolita in Tehran, who discusses her favorite American novels in The Republic of Imagination: America in Three Books. “She is a master essayist who sinuously weaves together elements of memoir, criticism, biography and history,” wrote Laura Miller. “No one writes better or more stirringly about the way books shape a reader’s identity.”
ShortDesc: Sandra Cisnero’s new book is A House of My Own. Azar Nafisi is author of The Republic of Imagination.
Title: Sandra Cisneros and Azar Nafisi

MobileDesc: An evening of reading and discussion to celebrate the great Italian writer upon publication of his Collected Works, which is edited by Ann Goldstein and features many new translations of his work. “With the moral stamina and intellectual pose of a twentieth-century titan, this slightly built, dutiful, unassuming chemist set out systematically to remember the German hell on earth, steadfastly to think it through, and then to render it comprehensible in lucid, unpretentious prose,” wrote Philip Roth.
ShortDesc: An evening of reading and discussion to celebrate the great Italian writer upon publication of his Collected Works, which is edited by Ann Goldstein and features many new translations of his work.
Title: A Celebration of Primo Levi

MobileDesc:
“Adrian Tomine has more ideas in twenty panels than novelists have in a lifetime,” wrote Zadie Smith.

The artist behind the comic-book series Optic Nerve, which he began self-publishing at the age of 16, is known for his New Yorker covers and the graphic novels 32 Stories, Sleepwalk and Summer Blonde. His new book, Killing and Dying, is a stunning showcase of the possibilities of the medium and a wry exploration of loss, creative ambition, identity and family dynamics.
ShortDesc: Adrian Tomine’s new graphic novel, Killing and Dying, is a stunning showcase of the possibilities of the medium and a wry exploration of loss, creative ambition, identity and family dynamics.
Title: Adrian Tomine

MobileDesc:
Poet Yusef Komunyakaa and actor Wendell Pierce—both Louisiana natives—share a stage for the first time.

Komunyakaa’s new collection is The Emperor of Water Clocks. “His voice, whether it embodies the specific experiences of a black man, a soldier in Vietnam, or a child in Bogalusa, Louisiana, is universal. It shows us in ever deeper ways what it is to be human,” wrote Toi Derricotte. Ten years after Hurricane Katrina, Pierce ("The Wire" and "Treme"), writes about “art’s power to transform us and the world” in his new memoir, The Wind in the Reeds: A Storm, A Play, and the City That Would Not Be Broken.
ShortDesc: Poet Yusef Komunyakaa and actor Wendell Pierce—both Louisiana natives—share a stage for the first time.
Title: Yusef Komunyakaa and Wendell Pierce

MobileDesc: Author of the acclaimed epics Cloud Atlas, The Bone Clocks and The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet, David Mitchell reads from his new novel, Slade House, a time-bending thriller he started as a Twitter story and could not let go of. “David Mitchell is one of the most fascinating and fearless writers alive,” wrote Dave Eggers. “He plays with narrative structure while never abandoning a traditional love of storytelling and an unmistakable affection for historical and ad-venturesome settings.”
ShortDesc: Author of the acclaimed epics Cloud Atlas, The Bone Clocks and The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet, David Mitchell reads from his new novel, Slade House, a time-bending thriller he started as a Twitter story and could not let go of.
Title: David Mitchell

MobileDesc: John Irving explores fate and memory in his new novel, Avenue of Mysteries, which follows an old man on a journey to the Philippines and back into the dreams of his childhood. “It’s impossible to imagine the literary landscape without John Irving,” wrote Time magazine. “He is as close as one gets to a contemporary Dickens.”
ShortDesc: John Irving explores fate and memory in his new novel, Avenue of Mysteries, which follows an old man on a journey to the Philippines and back into the dreams of his childhood.
Title: John Irving

MobileDesc: Kay Ryan’s new book of poems is Erratic Facts. “She loves to study the fallacies of the mind, to watch the eye make mistakes, to pay tribute to the spooky mystery of nature’s whole bestiary,” wrote the Los Angeles Times. “Her lines have a contagious skepticism to them, leaving us to emerge from her poems feeling not cleansed but quieted. That intense slowing is poetry’s great purpose—how it gets us to see.”
ShortDesc: Kay Ryan’s new book of poems is Erratic Facts.
Title: Kay Ryan

MobileDesc:
Poet Claudia Rankine reads from Citizen, her recent meditation on race in America, then sits for a conversation on art, trauma and social justice with Cleonie White and Sarah Stemp, clinicians from the William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Society.

“Claudia Rankine’s Citizen comes at you like doom,” wrote Hilton Als. “It’s the best note in the wrong song that is America. Its various realities—‘mistaken’ identity,’ social racism, the whole fabric of urban and suburban life—are almost too much to bear, but you bear them, because it’s the truth.”
ShortDesc: Poet Claudia Rankine reads from Citizen, her recent meditation on race in America, then sits for a conversation on art, trauma and social justice with Cleonie White and Sarah Stemp, clinicians from the William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Society.
Title: Claudia Rankine

MobileDesc: A celebration of the Israeli poet of love and landscape upon publication of The Poetry of Yehuda Amichai, a collection from Robert Alter that assembles the best of existing translations and his own new versions. “Amichai is one of the biggest, most essential, most durable poetic voices of this past century—one of the most intimate, alive and human, wise, humorous, true, loving, inwardly free and resourceful, at home in every human situation,” wrote Ted Hughes.
ShortDesc: A celebration of the Israeli poet of love and landscape upon publication of The Poetry of Yehuda Amichai, a collection from Robert Alter that assembles the best of existing translations and his own new versions.
Title: A Celebration of Yehuda Amichai

MobileDesc:
A rare US appearance by László Krasznahorkai—the “contemporary Hungarian master of apocalypse,” wrote Susan Sontag. Winner of this year’s Man Booker International Prize, Krasznahorkai is author of The Melancholy of Resistance, Satantango and Seiobo There Below. His new collection of nonfiction is Destruction and Sorrow Beneath the Heavens: Reportage.

He is joined by one of his biggest local admirers, Salman Rushdie, whose new novel, Two Years, Eight Months and Twenty-Eight Nights, is set in a New York of the near future made strange after a massive storm. “He is rare and magical writer,” wrote Michael Chabon.
ShortDesc: A rare US appearance by László Krasznahorkai—the “contemporary Hungarian master of apocalypse,” wrote Susan Sontag. Salman Rushdie’s new novel is Two Years, Eight Months and Twenty-Eight Nights.
Title: László Krasznahorkai and Salman Rushdie

MobileDesc: A celebration of the Polish Nobel Laureate upon publication of Map: Collected and Last Poems. “Her poetry had the gift of creating both the happiness of wisdom felt and the ecstatic happiness of the particulars of life fully imagined,” wrote Adam Gopnik. “From the experience of armies and dogmas and death that shaped her early life, she found a new commitment to the belief that the poetic impulse, however small its objects, is always saner than the polemical imperative, however passionate its certitudes.”
ShortDesc: A celebration of the Polish Nobel Laureate upon publication of Map: Collected and Last Poems.
Title: A Celebration of Wisława Szymborska

MobileDesc:
In The Past, British novelist Tessa Hadley turns her astute eye to a family reunion where simmering tensions and secrets rise to the surface. “Hadley is as perceptive as Alice Munro in teasing out the subtle changes in the emotional temperature,” wrote Ruth Franklin.

With Golden Age, Jane Smiley completes her bestselling Langdon family trilogy. “What Smiley feels most like here—for her faultless skills in bringing a wide cast so vividly into being that we would know them anywhere and her combination of impatient intellect, emotional perspicacity and unfailing humanity—is America’s Tolstoy,” wrote The Guardian.
ShortDesc: Tessa Hadley’s new novel is The Past. Jane Smiley’s new novel is Golden Age.
Title: Tessa Hadley and Jane Smiley

MobileDesc: “Ah, seventy … your work is triumphant, you pee like a Palomino pony, and your imagination is more vivid than ever before,” writes Garrison Keillor. Having recently celebrated his 40th anniversary as creator, writer and host of A Prairie Home Companion, Keillor returns to 92Y for a light-hearted evening of reading and reminiscing.
ShortDesc: “Ah, seventy … your work is triumphant, you pee like a Palomino pony, and your imagination is more vivid than ever before,” writes Garrison Keillor.
Title: Garrison Keillor

MobileDesc:
Rediscover Shakespeare with two quick-witted storytellers renowned for their imagination and scholarship.

Howard Jacobson, who won the Booker Prize for The Finkler Question, rewrites Shakespeare in his new novel, Shylock is My Name. "His writing has the kind of energy that you have to look at through your fingers, like an eclipse,” wrote Jonathan Safran Foer. “As the brightness of his brilliance is hard to look at, so is the darkness of his humor. I don’t know a funnier writer alive.”

James Shapiro’s Shakespeare and the Jews—soon to be reissued in a 20th-anniversary edition—was an important influence on Jacobson’s novel. In his new work of scholarship, The Year of Lear, Shapiro shows how the tumultuous events in England in 1606 shaped the three tragedies Shakespeare wrote that year—King Lear, Macbeth and Antony and Cleopatra. “His gift as a literary historian is to combine great good sense with daring imaginative reach—so that as we read his pages, we simultaneously look down into the workings of Shakespeare’s mind and around him at the landscape of his times,” wrote Andrew Motion.
ShortDesc: Rediscover Shakespeare with two quick-witted storytellers renowned for their imagination and scholarship.
Title: Howard Jacobson and James Shapiro

MobileDesc:
Author of The Liars’ Club, Cherry and Lit, Mary Karr has now written “another astonishingly perceptive, wildly entertaining and profoundly honest book,” wrote Cheryl Strayed. “Funny, fascinating, necessary, The Art of Memoir will be the definitive book on reading and writing memoir for years to come.”

Helen MacDonald’s H is for Hawk is “the discovery of the season,” wrote The Economist. “One part memoir, one part gorgeous evocation of the natural world and one part literary meditation—lit with a grace that sweeps down to the reader to hold her wrist tight with beautiful, terrible claws.”
ShortDesc: Mary Karr’s new book is The Art of the Memoir. Helen Macdonald is author of H is for Hawk.
Title: Mary Karr and Helen Macdonald

MobileDesc:
An evening with two poets also highly regarded for their prose.

“No other poet now writing has Susan Howe’s power to bring together narative and lyric, scholarship and historical speculation, found text and pure invention,” wrote Marjorie Perloff. Howe’s new essay collection is The Quarry. Ben Lerner has written three books of poetry (most recently Mean Free Path) and two novels (Leaving Atocha Station and 10:04) “A writer of true originality,” wrote Jeffrey Eugenides. “He is a courageous, immensely intelligent artist who panders to no one and yet is a delight to read.”
ShortDesc: An evening with two poets also highly regarded for their prose.
Title: Susan Howe and Ben Lerner

MobileDesc: Anne Carson reads from FLOAT, her new book of poetry. “Reading her books is both an exhilarating and a bewildering experience,” writes Charles Simic. “Carson takes risks, subverts literary conventions and plays havoc with our expectations. She is a wonder: an unconventional, often difficult poet with a huge following.”
ShortDesc: Anne Carson reads from FLOAT, her new book of poetry.
Title: Anne Carson

MobileDesc:
The Joan Leiman Jacobson Poetry Prizes are, for the ninth year, presented by 92Y and Boston Review. Over the decades, this contest has discovered such poets as John Ashbery, Lucille Clifton, Mark Strand, Mary Jo Bang and Gregory Orr. Visit 92Y.org/Discovery to apply.

This year’s judges are Ellen Bryant Voigt, Thylias Moss and Paul Muldoon.
ShortDesc: The Joan Leiman Jacobson Poetry Prizes are presented by the 92Y Unterberg Poetry Center and Boston Review.
Title: Discovery/Boston Review Poetry Contest Winners' Reading

MobileDesc:
Louise Erdrich’s new novel is LaRose. "For nearly three decades, she has been populating her novels with indelible characters from her North Dakota homeland--people who have intermingled, waged war and loved mightily for more than a century," wrote the Boston Globe. “Each new Erdrich novel adds new layers of pathos and comedy, earthiness and spiritual questing, to her priceless multigenerational drama."

Anne Enright won the Man Booker Prize for The Gathering. Her new novel, The Green Road, has been long-listed for this year’s prize. "Her style is as sharp and brilliant as Joan Didion's, and the scope of her understanding is as wide as Alice Munro's," wrote Colm Tóibín. "Her vision of Ireland is as brave and original as Edna O'Brien's."
ShortDesc: Erdrich’s new novel is LaRose. Enright’s The Green Road has been nominated for the Man Booker Prize.
Title: Louise Erdrich and Anne Enright

MobileDesc: The product of thirty years of friendship and conversation, Jay Parini’s Empire of Self: A Life of Gore Vidal is an intimate, authorized yet frank biography of one of the most accomplished, visible and controversial novelists and cultural figures of the past century. “Probably no other American writer since Ernest Hemingway lived his life so much in the public eye,” writes Parini, whose other biographical subjects include Robert Frost, John Steinbeck, William Faulkner and Jesus.
ShortDesc: The product of thirty years of friendship and conversation, Jay Parini’s Empire of Self: A Life of Gore Vidal is an intimate, authorized yet frank biography of one of the most accomplished, visible and controversial novelists and cultural figures of the past century.
Title: Jay Parini on Gore Vidal

MobileDesc:
Now published for the first time in new translations by editors Brian Boyd and Olga Voronina, Nabokov’s Letters to Véra—his wife, muse and lifelong partner—tell a long and beguiling love story and document anew the creative energies of a brilliant artist who was always at work.

Professor Voronina will sit for a conversation with critic and translator Wyatt Mason, who has written that “Nabokov’s letters are pure reading pleasure.”
ShortDesc: Now published for the first time in new translations by editors Brian Boyd and Olga Voronina, Nabokov’s Letters to Véra—his wife, muse and lifelong partner—tell a long and beguiling love story and document anew the creative energies of a brilliant artist who was always at work.
Title: Olga Voronina on Nabokov’s Letters to Véra

MobileDesc: In celebration of Anthony Trollope’s bicentenary, Adam Gopnik pays tribute to one of his favorite novelists. “Beyond saying that his writing feels like life, it’s hard to say just how he works his magic,” Gopnik writes. “Sanity, sympathy, worldliness, broad-minded ambivalence about change—these are the usual attributes of a major administrator, rather than of a major artist. Trollope is that rare thing: a strong writer with a trustworthy imagination.”
ShortDesc: In celebration of Anthony Trollope’s bicentenary, Adam Gopnik pays tribute to one of his favorite novelists.
Title: Adam Gopnik on Anthony Trollope

MobileDesc: David Orr presents a cultural biography of Robert Frost’s famous poem in The Road Not Taken. Is the poem—first published 100 years ago—a paean to self-assertion or a commentary on self-deception? Poetry columnist for The New York Times, Orr is the perfect guide to illuminate the poem’s enduring greatness while revealing its mystifying contradictions.
ShortDesc: David Orr presents a cultural biography of Robert Frost’s famous poem in The Road Not Taken.
Title: David Orr on Robert Frost

MobileDesc: Benjamin Taylor’s new biography of the master novelist is Proust: The Future’s Secret. “His endeavor is not to explain the life by the novel or the novel by the life but to show how different events, different emotional upheavals, fired Proust’s imagination,” wrote Anka Muhlstein. “The result is a very subtle, thought-provoking book.”
ShortDesc: Benjamin Taylor’s new biography of the master novelist is Proust: The Future’s Secret.
Title: On Proust with Benjamin Taylor

MobileDesc: Claire Harman’s new biography of Charlotte Brontë—timed to her bicentenary—explores the life of a literary visionary and feminist trailblazer that contained all the drama and tragedy of the great Gothic novels (Jane Eyre, Villette, Shirley, The Professor) that it inspired. Harman has written acclaimed biographies of Robert Louis Stevenson, Sylvia Townsend Warner and Fanny Burney, as well as Jane’s Fame: How Jane Austen Conquered the World.
ShortDesc: Claire Harman’s new biography of Charlotte Brontë—timed to her bicentenary—explores the life of a literary visionary and feminist trailblazer that contained all the drama and tragedy of the great Gothic novels (Jane Eyre, Villette, Shirley, The Professor) that it inspired.
Title: On Charlotte Brontë with Claire Harman

MobileDesc: In Eternity’s Sunrise: The Imaginative World of William Blake, Leo Damrosch—acclaimed biographer of Swift, Rousseau and Toqueville—draws extensively on Blake’s poems, paintings, etchings and engravings to offer a generously illustrated account of Blake the man and Blake the visionary. “This luminous new book on William Blake forsakes esoteric scholarship and addresses itself to the common reader who is invited to a festive celebration of the great English poet,” wrote Harold Bloom.
ShortDesc: In Eternity’s Sunrise: The Imaginative World of William Blake, Leo Damrosch—acclaimed biographer of Swift, Rousseau and Toqueville—draws extensively on Blake’s poems, paintings, etchings and engravings to offer a generously illustrated account of Blake the man and Blake the visionary.
Title: On William Blake with Leo Damrosch

MobileDesc: Hannah Arendt was one of the most gifted and provocative voices of her era. Drawing upon interviews with Arendt’s surviving students, friends and relatives, along with exhaustive archival research, Anne Heller—author of Ayn Rand and the World She Made—tracks the source of Arendt’s contradictions and greatest achievements in Hannah Arendt: A Life in Dark Times.
ShortDesc: Hannah Arendt was one of the most gifted and provocative voices of her era.
Title: Anne Heller on Hannah Arendt

MobileDesc: Author of the classic memoir The Color of Water, James McBride travels the country tracking the legend of James Brown in his new work of nonfiction, Kill ’Em and Leave. What he discovers is a complicated story of race, music, the South and America today. McBride won the 2013 National Book Award for his novel The Good Lord Bird, which was praised by the NBA judges for possessing a “voice as comic and original as any we have heard since Mark Twain—daringly irreverent, but also wise, funny and affecting.”
ShortDesc: Author of the classic memoir The Color of Water, James McBride travels the country tracking the legend of James Brown in his new work of nonfiction, Kill ’Em and Leave.
Title: James McBride

MobileDesc:
Over the years, the Poetry Center has teamed with The Paris Review to present numerous onstage conversations—with Chinua Achebe, Norman Mailer, Iris Murdoch, Maya Angelou, Günter Grass, Tony Kushner, Denise Levertov, Salman Rushdie, Czesław Miłosz, Arthur Miller and many others—that have often led to Writers-at-Work interviews appearing in the magazine.

In this latest installment, poet Nathaniel Mackey—winner of this year's Bollingen Prize—will read from his work and sit for a conversation with Cathy Park Hong. "His poetry ambitiously continues an American bardic line that unfolds from Leaves of Grass to Pound’s Cantos to H.D.’s Trilogy to Olson’s The Maximus Poems, winds through the whole of Robert Duncan’s work and extends beyond all of these,” wrote Don Share. “Mackey’s own rare combinations create an astonishing and resounding effect: his words go where music goes.”
ShortDesc: Over the years, the Poetry Center has teamed with The Paris Review to present numerous onstage conversations that have often led to Writers-at-Work interviews appearing in the magazine.
Title: Nathaniel Mackey with Cathy Park Hong: A Live Paris Review Writers-at-Work Interview

MobileDesc: We’re beyond excited to be hosting a #FierceReads event! Join us for YA conversation and a panel of devastatingly good writers, including Leigh Bardugo (Six of Crows), Leila Sales (Tonight the Streets Are Ours), Emma Mills (First & Then) and Josephine Agnelini (Firewalker).
ShortDesc: We’re beyond excited to be hosting a #FierceReads event!
Title: YA Lit at 92Y: Fierce Reads Tour

MobileDesc:
This is the launch event for Queen of Shadows, the fourth novel in the Throne of Glass series. A book signing will take place after the event.

Purchase of Queen of Shadows is required to join signing line. Signing is limited to 3 books per person.
ShortDesc: This is the launch event for Queen of Shadows, the fourth novel in the Throne of Glass series.
Title: YA Lit at 92Y: Sarah J. Maas—Queen of Shadows in Conversation with Sasha Alsberg

MobileDesc: Master storyteller David Baldacci, whose new YA title is The Keeper, joins the bestselling partnership Cassandra Clare and Holly Black to discuss the new volume in their Magisterium collaboration, The Copper Gauntlet.
ShortDesc: Master storyteller David Baldacci, whose new YA title is The Keeper, joins the bestselling partnership Cassandra Clare and Holly Black to discuss the new volume in their Magisterium collaboration, The Copper Gauntlet.
Title: David Baldacci, Cassandra Clare and Holly Black

ShortDesc: “The perfect venue for literary engagement, for becoming a believer in the magic and power of the word.” — Junot Diaz
Title: Poetry Center - Choose Any Three Events
